summary: This is an email chain from December 2020 discussing the scheduling of a ruling on Ghislaine Maxwell's renewed bail motion and the procedural status of the government's sealed response filing. It involves coordination between DOJ personnel regarding public website updates.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: The judge who is scheduled to rule on Ghislaine Maxwell's renewed bail motion and who required the government's response to be filed under seal initially.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the renewed bail motion being discussed; the case is United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Nicholas Biase
persons.context: A recipient and participant in the email chain from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, asking for a copy of a filed response.

persons.name: Defense counsel
persons.context: Referenced as having 24 hours to object to the government's proposed redactions to the sealed bail response filing.

connections.description: Defense counsel is representing Ghislaine Maxwell in her criminal case and is tasked with objecting to redactions in the government's bail response.
Judge Nathan is the presiding judge in the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell and is ruling on her bail motion.
Biase, as part of the US Attorney's Office, is involved in the prosecution's correspondence regarding the bail proceedings against Maxwell.

events.title: Government files sealed bail response
events.description: The government filed its response to Ghislaine Maxwell's renewed bail motion, but Judge Nathan required it to be filed under seal with proposed redactions first. Defense counsel has 24 hours to object to the redactions.

events.title: Inquiry about bail ruling schedule
events.description: An email asks if Judge Nathan has scheduled a day to rule on Maxwell's renewed bail motion and whether the DOJ's public website should be updated accordingly.

keyFacts: Judge Nathan required the government's response to Ghislaine Maxwell's renewed bail motion to be filed under seal initially, with proposed redactions.
Defense counsel for Maxwell had 24 hours to object to the government's proposed redactions before the response could be publicly docketed.
The email chain shows internal DOJ coordination about updating the public Justice Department website once a ruling on the bail motion is scheduled.
The correspondence confirms the ongoing legal proceedings in United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell as of December 2020.
